stem: A client is 2 hours post-renal transplant. Based on the documentation in the Renal Transplant & Perfusion Log, which finding indicates hyperacute rejection?

tabs.title: Intra-Operative Note
tabs.content: Note: Transplant completed at 1100. Right after the clamps were released, the new kidney appeared pink and well-perfused. Urine started to drip immediately.

tabs.title: Post-Op (1300) Assessment
tabs.content: Current Findings: The kidney is now palpable, firm, and painful. Urine output has suddenly stopped (Anuria). The surgical incision site shows blue-ish discoloration over the transplant area.

tabs.title: Vital Signs & Labs (1315)
tabs.content: BP 182/104. HR 122. Temp 102.4Â°F (Fever). WBC 18,000. Creatinine rising from 4.2 to 5.8.

options.text: Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN) due to ischemia

rationale.correct: This is **Hyperacute Rejection (a1)**. The hallmark of hyperacute rejection is that it happens **within minutes to hours** of the surgery. It occurs because the recipient has pre-existing antibodies that immediately attack the donor organ, causing massive thrombosis (clotting) and cyanosis (blue color) of the graft. The sudden stop in urine, the high fever (102.4), and the painful, firm kidney are classic signs. The only treatment is **immediate removal** of the transplanted kidney.
clinicalPearls: Acute: 1 week to 3 months (Cellular response). Switch/Increase meds.
Chronic: Months to Years (Scarring). Back to dialysis.
Fever + Sudden Anuria + Pain = Rejection until proven otherwise.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the **TIMING**. Acute rejection cannot happen within 2 hours; the body takes time to 'learn' the new organ's antigens. Hyperacute is the ONLY one that happens on the operating table or in the first few hours.
